description.en: From the Platonic notion of memory as a wax block to Hegel's historical consciousness and Nietzsche's critique of historicism, the link between past and present has been an object of philosophical debate. The writings of Maurice Halbwachs on collective memory emphasize that memory is not entirely individual, but linked to particular groups. Gadamer's philosophical hermeneutics foregrounded the importance of interpretation, tradition and historical consciousness. Freud, on the other hand, was more interested in the traumatic aspect of past experience, rather than the past as a repository of tradition. The course ends with Derrida's hauntology as a substitute for ontology. In our discussions, we will examine what it means to be conscious of the past, to be influenced, determined or even haunted by past events. An underlying theme throughout the course will be the inability to fully capture and represent past experience in the present.
description.et: Side mineviku ja oleviku vahel on olnud filosoofiliste arutelude teemaks alates Platoni kirjeldusest mälust kui vahatükist kuni Hegeli ajaloolise mälu mõiste ja Nietzsche historitsismi kriitikani. Kursusel vaadeldakse Halbwachi, Gadameri, Freudi ning Derrida arusaamu minevikust ja mälust. Arutleme selle üle, mida tähendab olla minevikust teadlik, olla minevikusündmustest mõjutatud, determineeritud või isegi painatud. Õppeaine läbivaks teemaks on inimese võimetus minevikukogemust täielikult talletada ning olevikus edasi anda.

notes.et: Although memory is a "re-presentation" of the past, its impermanence seems to defy representation. Whether expressed in historical documents, novels, figurative monuments, poetry or film -- there is an explicit attempt to catch meaningful aspects of the past for future generations. Memory recalls and interprets the past in both their positive and negative aspects - as tradition and traumatic burden. During the course, we will read key texts that deal with the complex relationship of memory, history and tradition. From the Platonic notion of memory as a wax block to Hegel's historical consciousness and Nietzsche's critique of historicism, the link between past and present has been an object of philosophical debate. The writings of Maurice Halbwachs on collective memory emphasize that memory is not entirely individual, but linked to particular groups. Gadamer's philosophical hermeneutics foregrounded the importance of interpretation, tradition and historical consciousness. Freud, on the other hand, was more interested in the traumatic aspect of past experience, rather than the past as a repository of tradition. The course ends with Derrida's hauntology as a substitute for ontology. In our discussions, we will examine what it means to be conscious of the past, to be influenced, determined or even haunted by past events. An underlying theme throughout the course will be the inability to fully capture and represent past experience in the present. Readings include selections from Plato, Hegel, Nietzsche, Halbwachs, Gadamer, Freud and Derrida. The course is both in lecture and seminar format.

description.et:
45 min lecture+ 45 min seminar.
One time per week for 14 weeks.
Weeks 1-2:		Plato: memory as a wax block, knowledge as recollection; 
writing as both poison and medicine. 
Meno, Theaetetus and Phaedrus

Weeks 3-4		Hegel: historical consciousness and spirit of history
Hegel: Phenemenology of Spirit

Weeks 5-6: 	Friedrich Nietzsche: attention to how the past is remembered, as monumental, antiquarian and critical.
The Use and Abuse of History for Life

Weeks 7-8:	Maurice Halbwachs: the frameworks of memory, memory as a collective, the importance of generations.
The Collective Memory

Weeks 9-10		Martin Heidegger: historicity, tradition, heritage, language Being & Time  

Weeks 11-12: 		Sigmund Freud: return of the repressed, return to Plato's wax tablet, trauma, repetition and the talking cure, healing through memory.
Screen Memories, The Uncanny, 'Remembering, repeating and working through.'

Weeks 13-14:	Jacques Derrida: rethinking Plato's pharmakon, limit of representing the past, hauntology versus ontology.
Plato's Pharmacy and Specters of Marx.

audience.et: No prerequisites, but some philosophical background is desirable. The course is meant for advanced bachelor and master’s students.
